The reason these threads just keep going round and round is plain and simple: the premise we used to "rush" into war was unsubstantiated. When you stand up and tell your people we need to hurry up and invade a country because they have WMD's and represent a serious threat, you better be right. Everything that has come out of this administration afterwords comes under the category of "justifying our actions" because our original premise didn't pan out. The fact is, the atrocities against humanity that keep getting brought up occurred before and right after the original Gulf War, and that was 1991. That was over thirteen years ago, here is a quote from Jim's Trucking's link:
 
 "Investigators have identified six major crime periods: 1983 attacks on Kurds, a 1988 campaign against Kurds, chemical weapons attacks on Kurds 1986-88, the 1991 crushing of a southern Shi'ite revolt, 1991 crushing of Kurdish insurrection, and crimes against all sectors of the population during the entire period of Baath rule. " 
 
 I guarantee the majority of Republicans and Neo-Cons never would have signed off on this war as a "humanitarian" effort if it had been pitched that way to begin with. That's what makes all these posts so ludicrous. If we cared so much about the Kurds, why did we abandon them under Bush Sr. and sit back while they were slaughtered after the Gulf War in 1991? I must be the only one that sees the transparency of the modern day Republican, they deplore social programs that dole out tax monies to American recipients, yet they overwhelmingly support rebuilding a foreign country and trying to make life better for the Iraqi's.

Actually, the reason they keep going round and round is that the liberals can't understand or won't accept the truth.
 
 You don't know that WMDs were not there. Even though we haven't found many, you don't know that some are still not there. You don't know where they went. Surely, you agree that they were there at one time because Slick Willy and the gang said they were. He's even the first of the two to say that there was a link between Saddam and Al Quaeda. He and Kerry (and Edwards) all said Saddam should be deposed. Clinton signed a bill saying that our goal was to depose Saddam Hussein.
 
 Just because we haven't found great quantities of WMDs you now say that the premise was wrong and we shouldn't have gone in.
 
 The facts remain that the mass killings have stopped, the rape and torture has stopped, the Iraqi people are free and will soon elect their own leaders, etc. etc. The Iraqi people do not agree with you.
 
 The libs keep trying to degrade Bush's accomplishments by saying the WMDs weren't there. They are full of :xcensored !
 
 If you'd listen to someone besides the liberal talking heads and the liberal press, you'd learn the truth and shut up.

 
 And you don't know that the WMDs were there. You can speculate, but you can't prove it any more than I can prove they weren't. So where does that leave us? It leaves us with a search for proof of their existence, so far, none, or very little, has turned up.
 
 What is some? A couple of reports of very minor finds of possible weapons? Is "some" the amount that was claimed posed a threat to American freedom?
 
 How should people respond? How should the average Joe Sixpack respond when he's told his very safety is at risk due to Iraq's WMDs, then after we go in, the greatest military power with the greatest technology in the world, and are unable to provide any real concrete evidence of WMD's or an immediate threat. Should he feel deceived? Should he question the original assertion that there were WMDs?
 
 Or should he simply believe that because he was told they were there and that Iraq did have them at one time, that they are there, we just can't find them despite all our efforts and technology? 
 
 I'm a born skeptic. I won't take it on faith that the WMDs were there. I don't believe that some Iraqis in the desert can dismantle and hide every last WMD, enough to puportedly pose a serious threat to the safety of every American citizen, right under the noses of the most powerful and technologically advanced nation in the world. It's completely implausible IMHO.
 
 So what are Joe Sixpack's options? Well, he either raises a stink and wonders why he's potentially been lied to, REGARDLESS OF JOE'S POLITICAL AFFILIATION, or he does as Jim would rather him do, and shuts up and accepts the word of those that told him the WMDs were there.
 
 Is shutting up and accepting the "truth" the American way? "Well, the president and the next presidential candidate said they're there, they can't provide any evidence, but by golly, if they said they're there, they must be there. My gov't wouldn't lie to me, my gov't couldn't be wrong." When does blind faith take over from critical thought? 
 
 When will partisan finger pointing end - Bush this, Clinton that, and someone actually take charge? I find that INCREDIBLY frustrating as an observer of American politics.
 
 Liberating the Iraqis is great, it'll be even better if it actually works, but the current claims that it's the reason for going to Iraq or that it justifies the deception surrounding the WMDs is simply absurd. America as the liberator is laughable, that's been pointed out over and over again.
 
 Waxy

And you don't know that the WMDs were there. You can speculate, but you can't prove it any more than I can prove they weren't. So where does that leave us? It leaves us with a search for proof of their existence, so far, none, or very little, has turned up.
 
 What is some? A couple of reports of very minor finds of possible weapons? Is "some" the amount that was claimed posed a threat to American freedom?
 
 How should people respond? How should the average Joe Sixpack respond when he's told his very safety is at risk due to Iraq's WMDs, then after we go in, the greatest military power with the greatest technology in the world, and are unable to provide any real concrete evidence of WMD's or an immediate threat. Should he feel deceived? Should he question the original assertion that there were WMDs?
 
 Or should he simply believe that because he was told they were there and that Iraq did have them at one time, that they are there, we just can't find them despite all our efforts and technology? 
 
 I'm a born skeptic. I won't take it on faith that the WMDs were there. I don't believe that some Iraqis in the desert can dismantle and hide every last WMD, enough to puportedly pose a serious threat to the safety of every American citizen, right under the noses of the most powerful and technologically advanced nation in the world. It's completely implausible IMHO.
 
 So what are Joe Sixpack's options? Well, he either raises a stink and wonders why he's potentially been lied to, REGARDLESS OF JOE'S POLITICAL AFFILIATION, or he does as Jim would rather him do, and shuts up and accepts the word of those that told him the WMDs were there.

 When will partisan finger pointing end - Bush this, Clinton that, and someone actually take charge? I find that INCREDIBLY frustrating as an observer of American politics.
 
 Liberating the Iraqis is great, it'll be even better if it actually works, but the current claims that it's the reason for going to Iraq or that it justifies the deception surrounding the WMDs is simply absurd. America as the liberator is laughable, that's been pointed out over and over again.

You're kidding right? We didn't have the manpower to take Iraq in Gulf 1?! Now, there's a revisionist statement if ever heard one. emoticon_rolleyes

 
 Not at all. We had the manpower to roll in there and destroy their military, but not nearly enought to deal witht he internal situation after we did so. Backing off of Baghdad and leaving saddam in control was a decision made by Bush Sr because he hadn't deluded himself (as the current administration did ) into thinking that we would be met with flowers and the civilian population would line up to lick our soldiers boots clean. He didn't want to end up in a situation where our troops would be bogged down for years to come in an unwinnable war against a poorly defined enemy.
 
 Unfortunatly, baby Bush didn't have the same reservations. He and his staff managed to convince themselves that we could roll in there, crush the military, capture saddam, appoint our own government, and the iraqi people would be fine with this. They failed miserably in estimating civilian opposition. Bush Sr did not.
JPSartre12

Explain what you mean by "Bush 41 was tasked". Who tasked him in 1991? Who tied his hands and kept him from finishing his job? I hope your not going to hide behind the same UN that we discarded in 2003 when we decided their opinion was meaningless, or the world opinion we sluffed off to basically "go it alone" in Gulf War II. Saddam and all his atrocities were already documented (with the exception of slaughtering the Kurds in 1991 after we abandoned them) before Gulf War I, why the 13 year delay? I don't know how you can blame Clinton with a straight face and not address Bush I for not doing then what is so right now.

 
 Your argument makes no sense. You can't take conditions that existed in two different decades, separated by lots of world events, and try to draw a straight line through our performance in both. In 1991, the UN was in favor of liberating Kuwait and the US, having the deepest pockets and most guns in the UN, carries the bulk of the war effort.
 Then, the UN convinced GW1 that is wasn't in the ME's best interest to leave a vacuum in Iraq, so GW1 ended the war prematurely. Fast forward to 2003 .... NOW the US, having been burned by the UN several times since 1991 (Clinton fiascos like putting US troops under UN control in Somalia) , we no longer gave a rat's rectum what the UN thought and took actions that we felt were necessary to stop terrorism. Two different actions taken by two different Presidents separated by 12 years.
JPSartre12

Not at all. We had the manpower to roll in there and destroy their military, but not nearly enought to deal witht he internal situation after we did so. Backing off of Baghdad and leaving saddam in control was a decision made by Bush Sr because he hadn't deluded himself (as the current administration did ) into thinking that we would be met with flowers and the civilian population would line up to lick our soldiers boots clean. He didn't want to end up in a situation where our troops would be bogged down for years to come in an unwinnable war against a poorly defined enemy.
 
 Unfortunatly, baby Bush didn't have the same reservations. He and his staff managed to convince themselves that we could roll in there, crush the military, capture saddam, appoint our own government, and the iraqi people would be fine with this. They failed miserably in estimating civilian opposition. Bush Sr did not.

 
 Well, let's see. We did just roll in there, crush the military, capture Saddam and appoint our own government. AND Allied soldiers were met by Iraqis carrying flowers. I'll show you some photos sometime.
 I suggest that you talk to soldiers who have returned home from Iraq instead of watching too much ABC, CBS and NBC Nightly News shows. 
 The majority of Iraqis are grateful that the US liberated them and are looking forward to life after Saddam.
 If you consider that a miserable failure, consider how long we were in Germany and Japan after we beat both of those countries in WWII. All things considered, I'd say that we're way ahead of the timeline by comparison.
 
 emoticon_xgood
daewoo

Well, let's see. We did just roll in there, crush the military, capture Saddam and appoint our own government. AND Allied soldiers were met by Iraqis carrying flowers. I'll show you some photos sometime.

 
 I have a really neat vidoe of a bunch of Iraqis standing along the sides of the road cheering as a US convoy rolls in. Halfway down the road, those same cheering folks tunr around, grab RPG's and kalishnikovs, and open fire. 
 
 
 
I suggest that you talk to soldiers who have returned home from Iraq instead of watching too much ABC, CBS and NBC Nightly News shows. 
 The majority of Iraqis are grateful that the US liberated them and are looking forward to life after Saddam.

 
 I have talked to MANY soldiers who have come home. Thee seems to be a couple of differnt divides there, young kids who believe what their chain of command tells them, and older guys who have been around the block a few times and form their own opinion. I also know 4 guys whe went over as "private contractors" to act as translators and to help "organise nontraditional counterinsurgeny efforts".
 
 Yes, they run out with flowers and cheers, then go home and polish their rifles and attach deflective plates to their RPGs (makes them more effective against reactive armour) this is the way of the Arabs. Smile at you, then shoot you the second you turn around. This is the smart way to kill your enemy. When the enemy quites believeing your smiles and gifts (or gets translators who realise that those folkw ho are cheering as you go by are yelling "kill all Americans", which your 18 yr old soldiers grin at like XXXXXX), you end up with a situation like fallujah. We didn;t do real well in Fallujah, we basicaaly withdrew like whipped dogs and handed the city over to a guy who was a former baath party member who immediatly brought all the insurgents into his organisation and still has collected any heavy weapons from them (though it appears that they are re-arming from shipments that have been seized headed fro the city).
 
 There are two things to remember when attempting to divine public sentiment in an occupied country. Teh first is that the occupying troops are generally a pretty poor source. Not only do they generally not speak the language, they start out biases by their own cause. combat soldiers all over the world lie to themselves well when it comes to such things. This is a well documented emotional survival response. If you cannot convince yourself that you are fighting on the side of right, then you are just a murderer, and nobody want to deal with that. The other thing to rememebr is that the indigenous population will lie to your guys regarding public sentiment. This is a survuval mechanism for them, they don't want to be hauled off to abu ghraib to be "interrogated" for weeks.
 
 The last public poll by Bremer (before they decided they needed to classify them) showed 80% of Iraqis wanted us gone. I know a few iraqis that I have kept in contact with, and for the most part, it seems that most Iraqis want us gone. There is no possible way that the insurgents could be pulling off attacks like they have, and at the scale they have, and with the frequency that they have, without widespread support from their population. It is just not possible that they could conceal themselves in the general population, or keep themselves supplied, wihtout that support. 
 
 
 [/quote]If you consider that a miserable failure, consider how long we were in Germany and Japan after we beat both of those countries in WWII. All things considered, I'd say that we're way ahead of the timeline by comparison.[/QUOTE]
 
 There is absolutly no comparison between this situation and the one in Germany or Japan following WWII. For one thing, we flooded both those countries with troops. Allied troops made up at least 25% of the population of every major city in either place. Their population of miltary aged men had been largely killed off, and both countries industrial infrastructers had been completely destroyed. Neither one of those nations ever really fielded any type of civilian resistance to speak of. 
 
 Fast forward to today, in Iraq, and there are still plenty of young to middle aged men running around, the countries economic infrastructure has neot been completely destroyed, we have less than 200,000 troops in the entire nations and less than 2% of the Iraqis actually accept our appointed government as legitimate (reuters/BBC). Factor in that the Iraqi civilians are apparently willing and capable of putting together an effective civilian resistance, and anybody who is not completely blind should be able to see the differences here.
georged

Your argument makes no sense. You can't take conditions that existed in two different decades, separated by lots of world events, and try to draw a straight line through our performance in both. In 1991, the UN was in favor of liberating Kuwait and the US, having the deepest pockets and most guns in the UN, carries the bulk of the war effort.
 Then, the UN convinced GW1 that is wasn't in the ME's best interest to leave a vacuum in Iraq, so GW1 ended the war prematurely. Fast forward to 2003 .... NOW the US, having been burned by the UN several times since 1991 (Clinton fiascos like putting US troops under UN control in Somalia) , we no longer gave a rat's rectum what the UN thought and took actions that we felt were necessary to stop terrorism. Two different actions taken by two different Presidents separated by 12 years.

 
 Deep US Pockets? The 1991 Gulf War Cost $61 billion. Of that total, Kuwait, Japan and Saudi Arabia paid $50 billion. When oil went from $15 to $42/barrel in 1991, US multinational oil firms experienced a onetime profit of $30 billion, of which $20 billion was subject to $10 billion in US corporate taxes. That war cost the US $1 billion while the US consumer again swallowed the salami with higher fuel prices.
 
 Daddy Bush's book defined his reasons for not overthrowing Saddam and occupying Iraq, and they had nothing to do with UN influence. He reasoned it would result in the US having to 'rule' Iraq in a bottomless sinkhole of civil strife with little or no support from other UN members and no feasible exit strategy. Children often neglect the wisdom of parents, and ex-alcoholic born again Christians heed only voices in their heads based on mythology. And VPs urging them to be crusaders defending democracy to protect special interests.
JPSartre12

 I'm confused. Doesn't the US also include US consumers? emoticon_confused
